study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining motor imagery with actual execution could maximize motor skill improvement compared to actual execution alone.
results_summary: The study found that combining motor imagery with actual execution reduced absolute error more than actual execution alone, indicating greater motor skill improvement. However, motor imagery did not increase spinal motoneuron excitability, suggesting its role may lie in real-time prediction rather than excitability enhancement.
population_specificity: 25 healthy participants performing a force adjustment task with the left thumb and index finger.
effective_dosage: Six sets of repetitions of combined actual execution and motor imagery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether immersive VR enhances the effects of Action Observation and Motor Imagery (AOMI) on manual dexterity compared to traditional laptop-based AOMI.
results_summary: Both VR-AOMI and laptop-based AOMI groups showed significant improvements in manual dexterity, with VR-AOMI demonstrating faster improvements in left-hand tasks. Kinematic analysis revealed specific movement pattern changes contributing to functional gains.
population_specificity: 45 young volunteers

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a novel VR-AOMI intervention could enhance neuroplasticity in the motor cortex of healthy adults and identify predictors of neuroplasticity changes.
results_summary: The VR-AOMI task did not significantly increase MEP amplitude changes compared to the control, but regression analysis showed that participants with poor iTBS response in the control condition exhibited greater excitability after VR-AOMI. VR-AOMI may enhance neuroplasticity in individuals typically unresponsive to iTBS.
population_specificity: 20 right-handed healthy adults (13 females; mean age 23.0 ± 4.53 years).
study_duration: Two experimental sessions (VR-AOMI and control), duration not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically evaluate the effectiveness of motor imagery training (MIT) compared to conventional therapy on gait performance in individuals after stroke.
results_summary: MIT was found to be more effective than conventional therapy in improving cadence immediately post-intervention and at 1- or 2-months follow-up, as well as step length on both affected and unaffected sides. The study also noted improvements in walking endurance and functional mobility, though results were inconclusive due to significant heterogeneity among included studies.
population_specificity: Individuals after stroke

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and validate a new questionnaire (KMI-PFQ) to assess the ability to imagine pelvic floor muscle contractions using motor imagery in healthy women.
results_summary: The KMI-PFQ demonstrated good internal consistency, reliability, and convergent validity, with two key factors ("ability" and "mental effort") explaining 58.36% of response variance. No floor or ceiling effects were found, and the tool correlated positively with established imagery questionnaires.
population_specificity: 162 healthy Spanish women (mean age = 20.1 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of motor imagery (MI) on locomotion recovery in individuals with unilateral lower-limb amputation.
results_summary: MI showed early positive effects on the 10 m walking task during the pre-prosthetic phase and improved performance in the Timed Up and Go Test during the prosthetic phase. Additionally, fewer participants required walking aids after MI training, and the amputated limb's force was greater at the end of rehabilitation for the MI group.
population_specificity: Individuals with unilateral lower-limb amputation undergoing rehabilitation.
effective_dosage: 10 minutes per day, five days per week.
study_duration: Three weeks (pre-prosthetic phase) plus additional time during prosthetic phase (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the evidence on the use and efficacy of Motor Imagery (MI) interventions for neurorehabilitation in children with various neurological disorders.
results_summary: MI was found to be effective in 19 out of 22 studies, with uncertain results in the remaining studies. It was considered a reliable supportive or add-on rehabilitative tool for pediatric neurorehabilitation, though its effectiveness depended on the complexity of MI mechanisms related to the underlying disorder.
population_specificity: Children aged 5 to 18 years with neurological conditions such as cerebral palsies, stroke, coordination disorders, intellectual disabilities, brain/spinal cord injuries, autism, pain syndromes, and hyperactivity.
effective_dosage: Treatment sessions ranged from 1 to 24, with varying frequencies.
study_duration: Intervention duration ranged from 2 days to 6 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand muscle activation patterns during motor imagery (MI) and action observation (AO) tasks in stroke survivors to inform future rehabilitation protocols.
results_summary: The study proposed a protocol using electromyographic recordings to compare muscle activation during control, MI, and AO conditions, with the goal of improving stroke rehabilitation strategies. No specific results were reported in the abstract.
population_specificity: Stroke survivors with upper limb motor impairment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between motor imagery and foot pain, assessing its role in motor cortical reorganization and its potential impact on rehabilitation outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that motor imagery abilities were affected by conditions like leg amputation, chronic pain, and complex regional pain syndrome, with differences in brain activity and performance on motor imagery tasks. Treatment interventions incorporating motor imagery showed promising results in improving functional outcomes and reducing pain.
population_specificity: Participants with leg amputation, chronic leg pain, complex regional pain syndrome, and Achilles tendinopathy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of motor imagery combined with routine physical therapy against virtual reality plus physical therapy and physical therapy alone on balance, motor function, and activities of daily living in Parkinson's disease patients.
results_summary: The study found that motor imagery combined with routine physical therapy (MI + RPT) showed improvement in motor function, balance, and activities of daily living, but these improvements were less significant than those seen in the virtual reality plus physical therapy group (VR + RPT).
population_specificity: Sixty patients with Parkinson's disease.
study_duration: 12 weeks of intervention, with follow-up assessments up to one month post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare motor imagery (MI) abilities in children and adolescents with cerebral palsy (CP) versus typically developed (TD) subjects to inform MI-based therapies.
results_summary: Moderate evidence suggests CP patients have reduced hand recognition ability but similar whole-body recognition compared to TD controls. Limited evidence prevents clear conclusions on MI generation, mental chronometry, and MI-execution synchrony.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents with cerebral palsy (174 patients) and typically developed subjects (321 controls).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze connectivity changes between motor imagery (MI) and motor execution (ME) in brain areas (PMA and MA) to explore therapeutic targets for stroke patients.
results_summary: PMA and MA showed significant positive correlation during hand MI, with higher functional connectivity in stroke patients during left-handed MI. Synergy movements enhanced connectivity more than isolated movements during ME, with abnormal connectivity in the left PMA's 18th lead.
population_specificity: 23 stroke inpatients and 21 right-handed healthy individuals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how Motor Imagery Therapy (MIT) improves upper limb motor function in stroke patients by examining changes in functional connectivity within and outside the sensorimotor network.
results_summary: MIT improved upper limb motor function and daily activities in stroke patients, with greater efficacy when combined with conventional rehabilitation therapy (CRT) compared to CRT alone. MIT primarily enhanced interactions between the sensorimotor network and other brain networks, while CRT mainly facilitated functional reorganization within the sensorimotor network.
population_specificity: 26 hemiplegic stroke patients (13 in MIT group, 13 in control group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical effects of combining motor imagery-based neurofeedback training with bilateral repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation versus using bilateral repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation alone for upper limb motor function recovery in subacute and chronic stroke patients.
results_summary: Both therapies improved functionality and sensory function, but the combination therapy (motor imagery-based neurofeedback with bilateral repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation) showed superior effects in Fugl-Meyer Assessment and tactile/kinaesthetic sensory function across multiple time-points. No significant differences were found for hand-grip strength between the therapies.
population_specificity: Twenty individuals with subacute (n=4) or chronic stroke (n=16).
effective_dosage: 10 consecutive sessions of bilateral repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation alone (therapy A) vs. 10 consecutive sessions of bilateral repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation plus 12 non-consecutive sessions of motor imagery-based neurofeedback training (therapy B).
study_duration: 1-month washout period between therapies, with assessments before and after each therapy and at 15-day follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining action observation plus motor imagery (AOMI) with early sleep enhances gait and balance performance in older adults compared to AOMI alone or passive observation.
results_summary: Early sleep after AOMI training improved gait and balance abilities in older adults more than AOMI without sleep or passive observation, with benefits persisting at a 1-month follow-up.
population_specificity: Older adults (mean age 70.4 ± 5.2 years)
effective_dosage: 3-week training, sessions between 8:00-10:00 p.m. (AOMI-sleep) or 8:00-10:00 a.m. (AOMI-control)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify brain regions that could predict the effect of motor imagery (MI) training on neuropathic pain (NP) in pediatric complete spinal cord injury (CSCI) patients.
results_summary: MI evoked NP in some pediatric CSCI patients, with those experiencing NP showing larger gray matter volume (GMV) in the right primary sensorimotor cortex (PSMC) and insula. The combined GMV of these regions was an effective predictor (AUC = 0.824) for MI's effect on NP.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients with complete spinal cord injury (CSCI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the neural underpinnings, effectiveness, and clinical implementation of action observation (AO) and motor imagery (MI) as physiotherapy interventions for Parkinson's disease (PD).
results_summary: AO and MI training improved mobility and functional activities in PD patients, with neurophysiological data supporting brain network activation, though compensatory mechanisms were noted. Long-term effects remain uncertain, and study variability warrants cautious interpretation.
population_specificity: Individuals with Parkinson's disease (PD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of motor imagery (MI) on pain intensity and disability in individuals with complex regional pain syndrome (CRPS).
results_summary: The meta-analysis found moderate-quality evidence that MI improves pain intensity and related disability immediately, short-term, and long-term compared to a control group. The risk of bias was relatively low, but imprecision in results downgraded the evidence level.
population_specificity: Individuals with complex regional pain syndrome (CRPS).
study_duration: Immediate, short-term, and long-term effects were assessed (specific duration not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate kinesthetic motor imagery (KMI) processing in individuals with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) using a hand laterality judgment paradigm with eye-tracking methodology.
results_summary: Individuals with ASD showed lower accuracy and longer response times in KMI tasks compared to typical developing peers, with incorrect action representation affecting ASD participants more. Eye-movement patterns differed, with ASD individuals focusing more on objects while TD peers focused more on hand areas.
population_specificity: 22 individuals with ASD and 22 typical developing peers matched for age, gender, and intelligence.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of graded motor imagery therapy (GMI), repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS), and their combination in improving upper extremity function in stroke patients.
results_summary: Both GMI and rTMS improved upper extremity function, but the combination was significantly more effective. GMI was better than rTMS at increasing patients' interest in active training.
population_specificity: 56 stroke patients in a rehabilitation hospital setting.
effective_dosage: 30 minutes of GMI daily, 5 days a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if BCI-based training combining motor imagery with FES is more effective than conventional therapy for improving upper limb motor function in subacute stroke patients with severe paresis, and whether CST integrity influences outcomes.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in improvement between BCI and conventional therapy groups, though CST integrity was a significant predictor of functional recovery. EEG analysis showed changes in ERD patterns during unaffected limb motor imagery post-therapy.
population_specificity: Subacute stroke patients with severe upper limb paresis (ARAT <13).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the application of a nonlinear pedagogy (NLP) approach to motor imagery (MI) for skill acquisition in weightlifting beginners.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in exploration or performance outcomes between NLP and linear pedagogy (LP) conditions, with both groups primarily demonstrating sub-optimal barbell trajectories. The results suggest that learners self-organize their movements regardless of MI instructions to satisfy individual and task constraints while achieving improved performance.
population_specificity: Fourteen weightlifting beginners (two female and 12 male).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review and propose a unified framework combining motor imagery with transcranial electrical stimulation for improved motor rehabilitation, integrating cognitive domains like working memory, attention, and fatigue.
results_summary: The study found mixed results in motor imagery combined with transcranial electrical stimulation, suggesting the need for improved protocols. It proposed a theoretical framework integrating cognitive domains to enhance rehabilitation outcomes for neuromuscular and cognitive disorders.
population_specificity: Healthy and patient subjects (neuromuscular and cognitive disorders).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the relationship between improvements in motor function and changes in resting-state functional connectivity (rs-FC) after motor imagery interventions in stroke patients.
results_summary: All included studies reported improved motor function post-intervention and demonstrated a significant relationship between motor function changes and rs-FC alterations, particularly in sensorimotor networks and the parietal cortex.
population_specificity: Stroke patients with motor impairments.

study_goal: To determine if trunk training using motor imagery improves trunk control and balance function in stroke patients compared to routine rehabilitation therapy alone.
results_summary: The trial group showed significant improvements in trunk control, balance function, and motor recovery compared to the control group, with notable enhancements in affected-side muscle activity and reduced movement instability.
population_specificity: 100 stroke patients randomly divided into control and trial groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the neural mechanisms of motor imagery (MI) in older adults using fNIRS to compare brain activation during motor execution (ME) and MI.
results_summary: ME activated the left postcentral gyrus, while MI increased oxy-hemoglobin concentration in the right middle temporal gyrus, suggesting MI engages vision-related frontal-parietal cortex and tends to activate the right brain in older adults.
population_specificity: Older adults (20 participants; mean age 64.8 ± 4.5 years)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of graded motor imagery (GMI) and its component techniques (laterality recognition, motor imagery, mirror therapy) in reducing phantom limb pain (PLP) in amputees.
results_summary: All studies included in the review showed a decrease in PLP after interventions involving GMI or its techniques, with GMI application yielding the best results. The findings suggest that GMI and its components are effective in reducing PLP in amputees.
population_specificity: Amputees experiencing phantom limb pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test whether neuromodulation based on motor imagery and action observation could promote motor adaptation in a complex balance task and identify prior balance factors affecting adaptation.
results_summary: The experimental group using motor imagery did not improve motor adaptation rates and had longer adaptation times compared to the control group. However, the intervention benefited subjects with low proprioceptive participation in balance, while the control group's adaptation success depended on prior proprioceptive balance factors.
population_specificity: 48 healthy subjects

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how visual and visual-electrotactile stimulation feedback affects brain network reorganization during motor imagery tasks and its implications for motor rehabilitation.
results_summary: The study found that visual-electrotactile stimulation feedback improved information flow between motor-related and cognitive brain regions while reducing cognitive workload, but neither feedback modality significantly improved classification accuracy compared to no feedback.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely healthy or rehabilitation participants, but not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of motor imagery training on maximal force production in hip abductors and potential bilateral transfer effects in healthy participants.
results_summary: Motor imagery training significantly increased hip abductor strength (~8%) and improved imagery capability, with bilateral transfer effects observed in muscle strength and electromyography amplitude.
population_specificity: Healthy participants (n = 77)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the evidence for graded motor imagery and its phases (limb laterality, explicit motor imagery, and mirror therapy) in treating phantom limb pain.
results_summary: The study found that most research on phantom limb pain focuses on mirror therapy alone, with few studies examining the full three-phase graded motor imagery approach. Pain intensity was the most measured outcome, but dosing was inconsistent, and participant demographics varied widely, making comparisons difficult.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18+ with amputation and phantom limb pain, predominantly male (75%) with unilateral amputations (90%) of varying levels, causes, and durations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical application and intervention effects of Motor Imagery Brain-Computer Interface (MI-BCI) for improving upper limb motor dysfunction in stroke patients.
results_summary: The study found that MI-BCI positively improves motor dysfunction in stroke patients, as demonstrated through clinical and brain function evaluations, though it lacked detailed clinical operation demonstration.
population_specificity: Patients with moderate or severe upper limb motor dysfunction after stroke.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining Motor Imagery (MI), Feedback (F), and Action Observation (AO) improves archery accuracy more effectively than using fewer or none of these methods.
results_summary: The study found that combining MI, F, and AO led to significantly greater performance improvement in archery accuracy compared to using only F + MI or no intervention (Control group). The results suggest that integrating all three methods optimizes mental training for archers.
population_specificity: 60 young athletes (archers)
effective_dosage: Two training sessions per week, each involving two blocks of ten effective shots

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of graded motor imagery (GMI) on EMG activity, functional status, and emotional well-being in a patient with traumatic brachial plexus palsy.
results_summary: The study reported improvements in EMG activity, functional status, emotional well-being, and body awareness after 10 sessions of GMI therapy, suggesting peripheral motor effects and favorable functional outcomes.
population_specificity: A 24-year-old woman with left C7-T1 brachial plexus injury and radial nerve injury.
effective_dosage: 4 sessions of motor imagery and 6 sessions of combined motor imagery and mirror therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility of a four-class motor-imagery-based fNIRS-BCI for controlling a robot and compare performance between virtual and physical robot control.
results_summary: The study found significant improvement in classification accuracy between virtual and physical robot control, with differences in oxygenated hemoglobin activation patterns. Results suggest motor imagery can be enhanced with feedback and that a four-class fNIRS-BCI is feasible with sufficient training.
population_specificity: Thirteen participants (specific demographics not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combined action observation and motor imagery (AO + MI) could improve performance in a complex cup-stacking task without physical practice.
results_summary: AO + MI significantly reduced movement execution times compared to AO, MI, and control conditions at both post-test and one-week retention, demonstrating that complex motor tasks can be acquired without physical training.
population_specificity: Twenty-six participants (no further demographic details provided).
effective_dosage: Twenty trials per practice condition (AO + MI, AO, MI) on each of three consecutive days.
study_duration: Three consecutive practice days, with a one-week retention test.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of action observation plus motor imagery (AOMI) and somatosensory discrimination training (SSDT) versus no intervention on manual dexterity in healthy subjects.
results_summary: Both AOMI and SSDT significantly improved manual dexterity compared to no intervention, with SSDT showing a large effect size and AOMI a medium effect size. Improvements were observed in right-hand, left-hand, both hands, and assembly tasks, supporting the role of sensory stimuli in enhancing motor performance.
population_specificity: Sixty healthy right-handed participants.
effective_dosage: Not specified (interventions involved video observation plus motor imagery for AOMI and surface recognition/two-point discrimination tasks for SSDT).
study_duration: Not explicitly stated in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a colloidal chitosan-silver nanoparticles-fluoride nanocomposite (CCAgNPF) mouthwash compared to chlorhexidine in reducing salivary Streptococcus mutans in orthodontic patients.
results_summary: All tested mouthwashes (CCAgNPF, chlorhexidine, and their combination) reduced salivary S. mutans, with no significant difference between CCAgNPF and chlorhexidine alone. The combination of CCAgNPF and chlorhexidine showed the best results.
population_specificity: Orthodontic patients (n=45, divided into three groups of 15).
effective_dosage: Mouthwashes were used twice a day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of an herbal mouthwash (AA + TA), 0.2% CHX, and a placebo on gingival health, plaque control, and antibacterial activity against periodontal pathogens in children with plaque-induced gingivitis.
results_summary: Both AA + TA and CHX mouthwashes significantly reduced gingival and plaque scores and bacterial counts of P. gingivalis and T. forsythia over 21 days, with AA + TA demonstrating non-inferiority to CHX. The placebo group showed initial improvement but no significant difference between days 7 and 21.
population_specificity: 108 children with plaque-induced gingivitis
effective_dosage: Not specified (only concentration of CHX mentioned as 0.2%)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal concentration of lemon in mouthwash for relieving xerostomia and increasing salivary flow rate in hemodialysis patients.
results_summary: The 10% lemon concentration mouthwash was most effective for increasing salivary flow rate, while the 5% and 2.5% concentrations were better tolerated by participants. The findings suggest potential guidelines for xerostomia relief in this population.
population_specificity: Hemodialysis patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze changes in oral microbiota and the prevalence of antimicrobial resistance genes due to chlorhexidine (CHX) mouthwash treatment following periodontal surgery.
results_summary: CHX treatment reduced alpha-diversity in oral microbiota and increased the relative abundance of streptococci, suggesting a shift toward a caries-associated bacterial community. Although no significant changes in antimicrobial resistance genes (ARGs) were detected, there was an increase in genes encoding tetracycline efflux pumps.
population_specificity: 20 patients who underwent periodontal surgical procedures.
study_duration: 4 weeks of treatment, with follow-up 4 weeks after discontinuation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of a new mint mouthwash containing Lactobacillus plantarum in reducing plaque and gingival sensitivity while stabilizing oral microbiota.
results_summary: The mint mouthwash significantly reduced plaque (P ≤ 0.015) and gingival sensitivity (P ≤ 0.015) and helped stabilize oral microbiota compared to the control group. No adverse events were reported, and the product was well-tolerated.
population_specificity: 84 patients with a history of poor oral hygiene.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effect of mouth rinsing and gargling with mouthwash containing different concentrations of povidone iodine (PI) or hydrogen peroxide (H₂O₂) on the cycle threshold (CT) value obtained by RT-PCR, as a measure of viral load reduction.
results_summary: The study found that mouth rinsing and gargling with mouthwash containing 1% PI, 0.5% PI, 3% H₂O₂, or 1.5% H₂O₂ significantly increased CT values from baseline to postprocedural days 1, 3, and 5, indicating a reduction in viral load. The Friedman test showed significant differences among the groups.
population_specificity: Subjects recruited from Persahabatan General Hospital who met the inclusion criteria (n=69).
effective_dosage: 15 mL of mouthwash, gargled for 30 s in the oral cavity and 30 s in the back of the throat, three times per day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of Triphala and Curcumin mouthwashes to Chlorhexidine in managing gingivitis.
results_summary: Both Triphala and Curcumin mouthwashes were as effective as Chlorhexidine in reducing plaque, gingival, and bleeding scores, with Curcumin showing greater potential in reducing gingival inflammation. Herbal mouthwashes were considered safe alternatives with no side effects.
population_specificity: 81 patients of both sexes with gingivitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether total IgE screening could detect mouthwash allergic reactions associated with recurrent oral erythema multiforme (ROEM).
results_summary: The study found that alcohol-containing mouthwash exacerbated ROEM symptoms in a patient, and discontinuing its use, along with pharmacological therapy, led to clinical improvement and reduced IgE levels.
population_specificity: A 29-year-old woman with recurrent oral erythema multiforme.
effective_dosage: Not specified (patient was instructed to stop using alcohol-containing mouthwash).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of a herbal mouthwash versus chlorhexidine in reducing Streptococcus mutans count, plaque development, and gingival condition.
results_summary: The herbal mouthwash was found to be equally effective as chlorhexidine in reducing salivary Streptococcus mutans count and improving plaque and gingival scores.
population_specificity: 22 adults aged 20-30 years.
effective_dosage: 10 mL twice daily (specific frequency inferred from standard mouthwash use).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a natural enzymes mouthwash in treating xerostomia compared to a benzydamine mouthwash.
results_summary: The natural enzymes mouthwash significantly improved symptoms of xerostomia, including cognitive perception of dry mouth, oromotor function, and reduced nighttime waking to drink water. It also improved Clinical Oral Dryness Score (CODS) and resting salivary flow rate compared to the control group.
population_specificity: 49 adult participants with xerostomia (48 completed follow-up).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether propolis mouthwash reduces the incidence of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) in ICU patients compared to chlorhexidine mouthwash.
results_summary: Propolis mouthwash significantly reduced VAP incidence compared to chlorhexidine, with lower rates on days 3, 5, and 7 (10.9% vs. 30.9%, 23.6% vs. 43.6%, and 25.5% vs. 47.3%, respectively). The results were statistically significant and clinically relevant.
population_specificity: ICU patients in Iranian hospitals.
effective_dosage: 15 cc of 0.06% propolis mouthwash twice daily (8 AM and 4 PM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of a prepared herbal mouthwash in maintaining oral health among school children compared to a 0.2% Chlorhexidine Mouthwash.
results_summary: The herbal mouthwash significantly reduced oral health indices (OHI-S, PI, PI-S, GI, BOP) by the 30th day, with sustained lower PI and GI scores observed up to the 120th day post-interruption, comparable to the control group.
population_specificity: 110 schoolchildren
study_duration: 30 days (with follow-up assessments up to 120 days)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the treatment of aphthous-like ulcers using dexamethasone mouthwash and low-level laser therapy.
results_summary: The study found that dexamethasone mouthwash and low-level laser therapy were used to treat persistent aphthous-like ulcers in a patient, though the abstract does not specify the treatment outcomes.
population_specificity: A 50-year-old patient with major aphthous-like ulcers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical effectiveness of different oral rinses (herbal mouthwash, chlorhexidine, and normal saline) in reducing symptoms of chronic gingivitis.
results_summary: Herbal mouthwash (HO) and chlorhexidine (CHX) showed significantly lower mean gingival and plaque index scores compared to normal saline (NS), with no statistically significant difference between HO and CHX.
population_specificity: 60 individuals aged 18-45 diagnosed with chronic gingivitis, inclusive of all sexes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of combining fluoridated toothpaste (FT) and mouthwash (MW), with or without sodium trimetaphosphate (TMP), on dental enamel demineralization in vitro.
results_summary: The study found that combining MW with FT provided greater protection against enamel demineralization than FT alone. MW supplemented with TMP (100F-TMP) showed superior effects compared to higher fluoride MW (225F), with lower mineral loss and higher phosphorus concentration in enamel.
population_specificity: Bovine enamel blocks (in vitro study).
effective_dosage: 1100 ppm F toothpaste, MW at 100 ppm F, MW at 225 ppm F, and MW at 100 ppm F supplemented with 0.4% TMP; treatments applied twice daily.

study_goal: To analyze the effects of over-the-counter whitening toothpaste and mouthwashes on orthodontic treatment outcomes.
results_summary: Whitening toothpaste and mouthwashes generally did not have favorable effects on most evaluated outcomes, such as color stability and shear bond strength, though they performed better in ion release from wires. Regular toothpaste sometimes showed better results, and in other cases, there were no differences compared to controls.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing orthodontic treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether amine fluoride mouthwash could prevent white spot lesions (WSLs) during fixed orthodontic treatment.
results_summary: The study found that amine fluoride mouthwash significantly reduced WSLs compared to standard oral hygiene with fluoridated toothpaste alone, with a mean decrease in WSLs from 2 to 1.54 in the experimental group after 6 months.
population_specificity: 50 patients undergoing fixed orthodontic treatment (25 in the experimental group, 25 in the control group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the activity and feasibility of benzydamine mouthwash in preventing and treating radiation-induced oral mucositis in head and neck cancer patients undergoing radiation therapy.
results_summary: The study found that 33.7% of patients responded to treatment (NRS < 5), with most patients being treatment compliant. However, 29.2% developed severe mucositis, and hospitalization rates increased over time, though benzydamine was generally well tolerated.
population_specificity: Head and neck cancer patients undergoing radiation therapy, predominantly male (80.9%), mean age 61.4 years, with advanced disease stages (T3-T4: 73.0%, N2-N3: 61.8%).
study_duration: Weekly assessments from baseline (start of RT) to seven visits (V1-V7)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of propolis mouthwash versus chlorhexidine mouthwash in improving clinical periodontal parameters in perimenopausal women with chronic periodontitis.
results_summary: Propolis mouthwash showed significant improvements in pocket probing depth, clinical attachment loss, and bleeding on probing compared to chlorhexidine, with greater reductions observed over 12 weeks. Both mouthwashes improved periodontal health, but propolis was more effective in reducing bleeding on probing.
population_specificity: Perimenopausal women with mild to moderate chronic periodontitis.
effective_dosage: 0.2% chlorhexidine mouthwash and 20% propolis mouthwash, used twice daily.
study_duration: 6 weeks of intervention, with follow-up at 12 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antibiofilm properties of mastic gum resin extract (MGRE) against S. mutans biofilm on titanium dental implant discs compared to chlorhexidine gluconate (CHX).
results_summary: Both MGRE and CHX significantly inhibited bacterial growth, reduced lactate production and turbidity, and showed limited bacterial adherence on titanium discs compared to the control. MGRE demonstrated antimicrobial properties against S. mutans, suggesting potential clinical use as a mouthwash.
population_specificity: In vitro study using S. mutans cultured on titanium dental implant discs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the virucidal effect of commercially available mouthwashes against acyclovir-resistant HSV-1 strains.
results_summary: All four tested mouthwashes significantly reduced virus infectivity, with essential oil-based and povidone-iodine mouthwashes being slightly more efficacious than chlorhexidine. The study demonstrated in-vitro antiviral activity against ACV-resistant HSV.
population_specificity: Immunocompromised patients with ACV-resistant HSV-1 infections.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of oxygen-enriched mouthwash as a pre-procedural rinse in reducing bacterial load in aerosols during ultrasonic scaling compared to chlorhexidine.
results_summary: The oxygen-enriched mouthwash significantly reduced bacterial load in aerosols compared to chlorhexidine, with statistically significant differences in colony-forming units (CFUs) on chest and shoulder areas.
population_specificity: 40 patients aged 20-40 years advised to undergo ultrasonic scaling.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chlorhexidine mouthwash (0.2%) could effectively decolonize bacteria in the pharynx of acute leukemia patients and reduce antibiotic use and fever frequency.
results_summary: Chlorhexidine mouthwash significantly eradicated Coagulase-negative staphylococci (CONS) in pharynx swabs (p-value = 0.000) and contributed to reduced antibiotic use and fever frequency in leukemic patients.
population_specificity: Patients with acute leukemia (n=33 in the mouthwash group).
study_duration: 5 days (2 days prior to chemotherapy until 3 days after chemotherapy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the antiplaque and anti-inflammatory effects of plant-based mouthwashes (Morinda citrifolia and Ocimum sanctum) against a conventional synthetic mouthwash (0.12% CHX) in patients undergoing fixed orthodontic treatment.
results_summary: The study found that using herbal mouthwashes (5% MC and 4% OS) alongside fluoride toothpaste and brushing significantly reduced plaque scores and lowered levels of inflammatory cytokines (TNF-α, IL-α, and IL-β) compared to brushing alone. The herbal mouthwashes performed comparably to the synthetic CHX mouthwash.
population_specificity: 75 individuals undergoing fixed orthodontic treatment.
effective_dosage: 5% Morinda citrifolia (MC) and 4% Ocimum sanctum (OS) mouthwashes (frequency not specified).

study_goal: To determine the effectiveness of Ayurvedic mouthwash "Draksha Guduchyadi Kashaya" in reducing the severity of oral side effects of chemo-radiation in head and neck cancer patients.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant reductions in the onset and intensity of mucositis, pharyngitis, laryngitis, xerostomia, and pain in patients using the Ayurvedic mouthwash compared to the control group using soda-salt mouthwash.
population_specificity: 70 head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC) patients undergoing radiotherapy or concurrent chemo-radiation.
effective_dosage: 50 ml of "Draksha Guduchyadi Kashaya" for 2 minutes, ten times daily.
study_duration: Duration of radiotherapy or chemo-radiation treatment (not explicitly stated in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether rose water mouthwash, combined with chlorhexidine, could reduce the incidence of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) in ICU patients compared to chlorhexidine alone.
results_summary: The study found that rose water mouthwash significantly reduced early-onset VAP but had no effect on late-onset VAP, mechanical ventilation duration, ICU stay, or mortality. No significant differences were observed in other outcomes between the two groups.
population_specificity: 80 surgical ICU patients under mechanical ventilation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical efficacy of a novel herbal mouthwash in managing chronic periodontitis and radiation-induced mucositis compared to standard treatments (chlorhexidine and soda saline mouthwashes).
results_summary: The herbal mouthwash showed significant reductions in gingival bleeding, plaque accumulation, and pocket depth in periodontitis patients, comparable to chlorhexidine. It also reduced the severity of radiation-induced mucositis and analgesic requirements, with acceptable taste and satisfaction reported.
population_specificity: 50 periodontitis patients and patients with radiation-induced mucositis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate a nanoemulsion-based polyherbal mouthwash (PHFX) containing Curcuma longa extract for its antibacterial effects against various oral pathogens compared to chlorhexidine acetate (CHD-A).
results_summary: The nanoemulsion-based mouthwash (PHFX1) demonstrated significant antibacterial effects against Gram-positive and Gram-negative oral pathogens, outperforming standard CHD-A at 3- to 4-fold lower concentrations. The formulation showed optimal physicochemical properties and high drug release efficiency.
population_specificity: Oral pathogens (Gram-positive: Streptococcus mutans, Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus pneumoniae, Bacillus subtilis; Gram-negative: Escherichia coli, Klebsiella pneumoniae).
effective_dosage: PHFX1 contained 0.5% w/w Curcuma longa extract, 1.5% w/w clove oil, 7.0% w/w Tween-80, 7.0% w/w Transcutol-HP, and 84.0% w/w water.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the use of concomitant medication in combination with a mouthwash containing delmopinol HCl 0.2% and compare its effects with other mouthwashes and placebo.
results_summary: The delmopinol HCl 0.2% mouthwash significantly reduced the use of antibiotics (27% lower) and nasal decongestants (53% lower) compared to placebo, particularly for respiratory infections (41% decrease in antibiotic use).
population_specificity: Patients with gingivitis participating in 8 randomized double-blind phase III studies.
effective_dosage: Delmopinol HCl 0.2%, delmopinol HCl 0.1%, chlorhexidine digluconate 0.2%, or placebo (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether mouthwash could effectively reduce SARS-CoV-2 viral load in the oral cavity and potentially lower transmission risk, particularly among medical workers.
results_summary: Mouthwash showed a positive impact on CT values (indicating reduced viral load) within 30 minutes of use, with chlorhexidine, povidone-iodine, and hydrogen peroxide formulations being particularly effective. However, no significant difference in overall viral load was observed between the mouthwash and control groups beyond this short-term window.
population_specificity: COVID-19 patients
study_duration: Immediate effects measured within 30 minutes; longer-term duration not detailed

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antibacterial and anti-inflammatory efficacy of an amla seed-mediated GO-Ag nanocomposite mouthwash in treating plaque-induced gingivitis compared to a chlorhexidine mouthwash.
results_summary: The nanocomposite mouthwash significantly reduced plaque, gingival inflammation, and colony-forming units in gingivitis patients, though it was not as effective as the chlorhexidine mouthwash. Both groups showed statistically significant improvements in clinical and biochemical parameters after 15 days.
population_specificity: 30 patients with plaque-induced gingivitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of a mouthwash containing Glycyrrhiza uralensis extract on halitosis and its antibacterial activity against halitosis-causing bacteria.
results_summary: The G. uralensis extract mouthwash significantly reduced halitosis prevalence and halitosis-causing bacteria compared to the saline control group, with notable effects immediately after use and 5 days post-treatment.
population_specificity: 60 patients visiting a dental clinic in Busan, South Korea, without systemic diseases causing halitosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of a dexamethasone-based mouthwash in preventing chemotherapy-induced stomatitis in patients with early breast cancer.
results_summary: The dexamethasone-based mouthwash reduced stomatitis incidence (38% vs. 55% in controls) and severity, with no severe oral infections reported. Adherence to the mouthwash regimen was high (87%).
population_specificity: Patients with early breast cancer receiving epirubicin and cyclophosphamide (EC) or docetaxel and cyclophosphamide (TC) therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of chlorhexidine mouthwash and its compatibility with sodium lauryl sulphate dentifrice, as well as the combined use of chlorhexidine and sodium fluoride in mouthwash.
results_summary: The study found that chlorhexidine mouthwash can be used without issues before or after brushing with sodium lauryl sulphate dentifrice. Additionally, chlorhexidine and sodium fluoride can coexist in the same mouthwash without reducing chlorhexidine's efficacy.
population_specificity: Patients with periodontitis (implied by context, though not explicitly stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of oil pulling versus chlorhexidine and other mouthwashes or oral hygiene practices in improving gingival health, plaque control, and bacterial counts.
results_summary: Oil pulling showed clinically significant improvement in modified gingival index scores compared to non-chlorhexidine mouthwashes, but chlorhexidine was more effective in reducing plaque. The overall quality of evidence was very low.
population_specificity: Participants included both those with no reported oral health issues and others (specific conditions not detailed).
effective_dosage: Not specified (half of trials used sesame oil).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether a sodium-hyaluronate mouthwash reduces xerostomia symptoms in head and neck cancer patients post-radiotherapy compared to a placebo, and to assess its impact on quality of life and patient satisfaction.
results_summary: The sodium-hyaluronate mouthwash significantly reduced xerostomia symptoms compared to placebo (p=0.01) and showed higher patient satisfaction (p=0.001), with no reported adverse events.
population_specificity: Head and neck cancer patients suffering from radiotherapy-induced xerostomia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a 0.05% CPC-CHX mouthwash reduced SARS-CoV-2 viral load in saliva compared to sterile water.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant reduction in SARS-CoV-2 viral load after using the CPC-CHX mouthwash compared to the control group, with no differences observed across time points or vaccination status.
population_specificity: Forty SARS-CoV-2 positive patients.
effective_dosage: 15 mL of 0.05% CPC-CHX mouthwash, rinsed for 60 seconds.
study_duration: Saliva samples were collected at 15, 30, and 60 minutes post-rinsing.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of mastic mouthwash on halitosis (measured via Volatile Sulfur Compounds) and its impact on plaque and gingival indices in adolescents undergoing orthodontic treatment.
results_summary: Mastic mouthwash significantly reduced hydrogen sulfide (H2S) levels compared to placebo, but no significant differences were observed for other VSCs, subjective malodour perception, or oral hygiene indices.
population_specificity: Adolescents (ages 13-18) undergoing orthodontic treatment with fixed appliances and initial VSCs levels above 150 ppb.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the antiplaque and antigingivitis efficacy of 0.25% lemongrass oil mouthwash versus 0.2% chlorhexidine mouthwash in orthodontic patients with gingivitis.
results_summary: The study found that 0.25% lemongrass oil mouthwash resulted in significantly lower plaque and gingival index scores compared to chlorhexidine mouthwash by the 14th and 21st days, suggesting it may be a viable herbal alternative.
population_specificity: 60 patients undergoing fixed orthodontic treatment with mild-to-moderate gingivitis.
effective_dosage: 0.25% lemongrass oil mouthwash and 0.2% chlorhexidine mouthwash, used twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if prolonged mouthwash use (60 seconds) reduces the prevalence of the oral pathogen Scardovia wiggsiae in pediatric patients.
results_summary: The study found that mouthwash initially reduced detectable Scardovia wiggsiae (from 27.8% to 8.3%), but the effect was not sustained, as recall samples returned to baseline levels (27.8%). No long-term benefits were observed.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients in healthcare/dental settings.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a mouthwash containing Lespedeza cuneata extract (LCE) in reducing halitosis and its antibacterial effects on halitosis-causing bacteria compared to a saline placebo.
results_summary: The LCE mouthwash significantly reduced halitosis both immediately and 5 days post-treatment, with a statistically significant decrease in halitosis-causing bacteria compared to the saline group. Subjective improvement was also greater in the LCE group.
population_specificity: 84 subjects recruited from M Dental Clinic in Busan, South Korea.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of 0.12% chlorhexidine (CHX) and Salvadora persica-based mouthwashes (SPM) in reducing oral Candida carriage and periodontal inflammation in smokers and non-smokers after non-surgical periodontal treatment.
results_summary: CHX and SPM were more effective than the control in reducing plaque index, gingival index, and probing depth in non-smokers. CHX was more effective than SPM in reducing oral Candida carriage in non-smokers, but no difference was observed among smokers.
population_specificity: Cigarette smokers and non-smokers with periodontal inflammation, as well as non-smokers with healthy periodontal status.
effective_dosage: 0.12% chlorhexidine and Salvadora persica-based mouthwash (specific frequency not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the short-term efficacy and safety of low-concentration betamethasone mouthwash compared to dexamethasone mouthwash for treating severe erosive oral lichen planus (EOLP).
results_summary: Betamethasone mouthwash showed superior efficacy in reducing erosive area, pain, and extending recurrence intervals at 2 weeks, though its advantage diminished by 4 weeks. No serious adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: Patients with severe erosive oral lichen planus (EOLP).
effective_dosage: Betamethasone (0.137 mg/mL) or dexamethasone (0.181 mg/mL) three times daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the effects of pilocarpine mouthwash on salivary flow rate in patients with xerostomia.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that pilocarpine mouthwash slightly increased salivary flow rates, but the effect was not statistically significant. Existing evidence does not support its effectiveness in relieving symptoms of xerostomia.
population_specificity: Patients with xerostomia (dry mouth).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Dexamethasone-Lidocaine-Vitamin B12 Mouth rinse (DLVBM) was more effective than Compound chlorhexidine mouthwash (CCM) in reducing oral pain, weight loss, and mucosal healing time in patients undergoing radiotherapy for nasopharyngeal carcinoma.
results_summary: DLVBM significantly reduced oral pain and weight loss compared to CCM, but there was no significant difference in mucosal healing time between the two groups. DLVBM may moderately improve prevention of radiation-induced mucositis and reduce treatment interruptions.
population_specificity: 133 patients with nasopharyngeal carcinoma receiving radiotherapy (total dose of 70 Gy).
study_duration: Duration of radiotherapy treatment (not explicitly stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antimicrobial activity of Scrophularia striata and Quercus infectoria extracts against cariogenic microorganisms and their potential for preparing an effective herbal mouthwash.
results_summary: The study found that Q. infectoria gall extract exhibited strong antimicrobial activity, which was enhanced synergistically with S. striata extract. The prepared mouthwash showed desirable organoleptic properties, antimicrobial efficacy, and stability over 60 days.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study targeting cariogenic microorganisms: S. mutans, S. sobrinus, and C. albicans).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether ketamine mouthwash could reduce acute toxicity (pain and opioid use) in head and neck cancer patients undergoing curative radiation therapy.
results_summary: The study is designed to evaluate pain response (combining pain scores and opioid use) as the primary endpoint, with secondary endpoints including daily pain, opioid use, dysphagia, sleep quality, feeding tube placement, and treatment breaks. Results are pending as the trial is ongoing.
population_specificity: Patients with pathologically confirmed head and neck cancer undergoing 70 Gy radiation with concurrent cisplatin.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of thyme mouthwash on intraoral halitosis, gingival index, and plaque index in patients with gingivitis compared to other mouthwash treatments and a control group.
results_summary: Thyme mouthwash significantly improved bad breath (VSC reduction) and gingivitis (GI reduction) compared to the control group and zinc acetate/CHX diacetate mouthwash, with no significant difference in plaque index reduction among groups. All treatments reduced VSCs, GI, and PI compared to baseline.
population_specificity: 60 gingivitis patients (30 women/30 men) who received initial periodontal treatment and oral hygiene instructions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of milk as a mouthwash versus an anti-hypersensitivity mouthwash in reducing dentin hypersensitivity after non-surgical periodontal treatment.
results_summary: Both milk and the anti-hypersensitivity mouthwash significantly reduced dentin hypersensitivity by days 15 and 30, with slightly more patients benefiting from milk, though the differences were not statistically significant.
population_specificity: Patients with generalized moderate-to-severe chronic periodontitis who underwent scaling and root planing (SRP) and developed severe dentin hypersensitivity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of chlorhexidine (CHX) mouthwash on oral mucosal cell vitality in orthodontic patients, comparing outcomes with and without its use.
results_summary: The study found that CHX mouthwash, combined with orthodontic treatment, significantly increased nuclear damage markers (MIC, KR, KL, BE) in buccal mucosal cells, indicating a deteriorating effect on cell vitality. Orthodontic treatment alone caused negligible changes, but the addition of CHX worsened nuclear indexes.
population_specificity: 34 orthodontic patients (14 males, 20 females, mean age 16.68±3.75 years).
effective_dosage: Ethanol-free 0.12% CHX mouthwash, used twice a week.
study_duration: One month of orthodontic treatment followed by one month of CHX mouthwash use.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the antiseptic efficacy of a 0.05% chlorhexidine + 0.05% cetylpyridinium chloride mouthwash on reducing microbial contamination of toothbrushes.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in total bacterial count between treated and control toothbrushes, but the treatment group showed a significantly lower number of live bacteria, indicating reduced microbial viability.
population_specificity: Orally and systemically healthy individuals
effective_dosage: 0.05% chlorhexidine + 0.05% cetylpyridinium chloride, immersion for 2 hours

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of synbiotic mouthwash versus normal saline mouthwash on preventing and controlling radiotherapy-induced oral mucositis in oral cancer patients.
results_summary: The synbiotic mouthwash significantly reduced oral mucositis severity compared to normal saline, with lower mucositis grades from the 7th session onward and a lower incidence of severe mucositis (11.59% vs. 36.45%).
population_specificity: 64 oral cancer patients undergoing radiotherapy.
study_duration: From a day before radiotherapy start until the end of treatment (6 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a mouthwash containing 0.075% cetylpyridinium chloride and 0.28% zinc lactate in reducing metabolic activity and microbial composition in a multispecies biofilm model.
results_summary: The study found that CPC + Zn mouthwash reduced metabolic activity, total biofilm count, and several pathogenic species, including Porphyromonas gingivalis and Streptococcus mutans, while preserving beneficial species. It was particularly effective against Prevotella intermedia and did not disrupt health-associated bacteria.
population_specificity: Multispecies subgingival biofilm model (33-species biofilm formed on Calgary device).
study_duration: 4 days (from day 3 to day 6 of biofilm formation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of various mouthwash types for treating oral mucositis (OM) in cancer patients undergoing radiotherapy or chemotherapy.
results_summary: GM-CSF was the most effective mouthwash for OM treatment, followed by vitamin E and natural drugs. Povidone-iodine outperformed chlorhexidine but was less effective than GM-CSF.
population_specificity: Cancer patients with oral mucositis due to radiotherapy or chemotherapy.
study_duration: Evaluated at one, two, and three weeks of treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of dexamethasone plus gentamicin mouthwash combined with total glucosides of paeony (TGP) in treating oral lichen planus (OLP).
results_summary: The study found that the combination of dexamethasone plus gentamicin mouthwash with TGP (Group B) had a significantly higher total effective rate (89.66%) compared to the mouthwash alone (Group A, 61.9%). Clinical manifestations, sign scores, and VAS scales improved in both groups, with significant differences favoring Group B (p < 0.05).
population_specificity: 48 non-erosive and erosive OLP patients without fungal infection.
study_duration: Follow-up at 2 weeks, 1 month, 3 months, and 6 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of atorvastatin 1% mouthwash in preventing radiotherapy-induced oral mucositis.
results_summary: The study found that atorvastatin mouthwash significantly reduced the severity of mucositis and pain intensity compared to placebo, with notable differences after 3-4 weeks of use.
population_specificity: Thirty patients undergoing radiotherapy.

study_goal: To evaluate the effect of an enzyme-based mouthwash on dental biofilm and salivary microbiome composition in adolescents with fixed orthodontic appliances.
results_summary: The enzyme-based mouthwash significantly reduced dental biofilm (Orthodontic Plaque Index) compared to placebo after 8 days, but did not significantly alter the richness or composition of the salivary microbiome. Minimal adverse effects were reported, including one case of nausea and two disliking the taste.
population_specificity: Young adolescents (14-18 years) undergoing treatment with fixed orthodontic appliances.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of 0.12% chlorhexidine (CHX) and a Salvadora persica-based mouthwash in reducing periodontal inflammation and salivary IL-1β levels in young light cigarette-smokers versus never-smokers after non-surgical periodontal therapy.
results_summary: The study found that neither 0.12% CHX nor the Salvadora persica-based mouthwash effectively controlled periodontal inflammation or reduced salivary IL-1β levels in young light cigarette-smokers, though never-smokers showed significant improvements in plaque index, gingival index, and probing depth.
population_specificity: Young light cigarette-smokers and never-smokers with periodontal inflammation.
effective_dosage: Twice daily for 2 weeks (0.12% CHX or Salvadora persica-based mouthwash).
study_duration: 2 weeks of mouthwash use, with follow-up at 3 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of turmeric mouthwash compared to benzydamine mouthwash in reducing the severity of oral mucositis and associated oral dysfunctions in head and neck cancer patients undergoing radiation therapy.
results_summary: Turmeric mouthwash significantly reduced the incidence and severity of oral mucositis (17.8% vs. 100% in the control group) and improved oral health status and dysfunctions compared to benzydamine mouthwash, with statistically significant differences (P = .001).
population_specificity: Head and neck cancer patients undergoing radiation therapy.
study_duration: Weekly during the entire course of radiation therapy (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of three commercial mouthwashes (chlorhexidine, Manuka, and Pro-Dental) on plaque, gingival, and bleeding indices in patients with chronic gingivitis.
results_summary: All mouthwashes reduced plaque, gingival, and bleeding indices over time, with no significant differences between chlorhexidine and Manuka. Pro-Dental showed significant differences compared to the other two mouthwashes at all observed time points.
population_specificity: 45 patients with moderate plaque and chronic gingivitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of rice husk extract mouthwash (RHM) and Kidodent mouthwash (KM) in reducing salivary Streptococcus mutans count in children.
results_summary: Rice husk mouthwash demonstrated a significant and equivalent reduction in S. mutans count compared to KM (p < 0.05), suggesting its potential therapeutic effect.
population_specificity: 45 children meeting inclusion criteria.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of aloe vera mouthwash versus 0.2% chlorhexidine mouthwash in reducing dental plaque and gingivitis in patients undergoing fixed orthodontic treatment.
results_summary: Both aloe vera and chlorhexidine mouthwashes significantly reduced gingival index, plaque index, and bleeding on probing from baseline to 21 and 35 days, with no significant difference between the two treatments. Aloe vera showed promising results without reported adverse effects.
population_specificity: 30 subjects undergoing fixed orthodontic treatment.
effective_dosage: 10 ml of 99.6% (w/v) aloe vera mouthwash or 10 ml of 0.2% chlorhexidine mouthwash.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of rhIL-11 mouthwash compared to Kangfuxin fluid in treating and preventing oral mucositis in chemotherapy patients.
results_summary: The study found that rhIL-11 mouthwash was more effective than Kangfuxin fluid in treating oral mucositis, with shorter healing times and significant improvement. However, it showed no advantage in preventing oral mucositis compared to routine oral care.
population_specificity: Chemotherapy patients (50 in the treatment group, 62 in the prevention group).
study_duration: 7 days (observed on the seventh day of treatment)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of a 2.5% propolis mouthwash for preventing radiotherapy-induced oral mucositis in patients with nasopharyngeal carcinoma.
results_summary: The study found that the 2.5% propolis mouthwash significantly reduced the severity of oral mucositis compared to the placebo, with statistically significant differences at weeks 2, 4, and 6. The mouthwash was deemed safe and effective for this purpose.
population_specificity: Patients with nasopharyngeal carcinoma undergoing radiotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of a mouthwash containing Sambucus williamsii var. coreana extract on halitosis and halitosis-causing bacteria.
results_summary: The mouthwash significantly reduced halitosis and halitosis-causing bacteria compared to the saline control, with statistically significant improvements observed after 1 day and 5 days of use.
population_specificity: 77 participants at Misoplant Dental Clinic in Busan, South Korea.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of probiotic mouthwash on reducing red complex bacteria levels in chronic periodontitis patients.
results_summary: The study found that probiotic mouthwash significantly reduced clinical parameters (gingival and plaque indices) and bacterial cell counts (T. denticola and T. forsythia) compared to placebo. The results suggest probiotic mouthwash is effective as an adjunct to scaling and root planing.
population_specificity: Chronic periodontitis patients aged 18-55 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to verify the clinical applicability of a mouthwash containing Sambucus williamsii var. coreana extract for preventing periodontal disease by evaluating its effects on oral health indicators and bacterial presence.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in periodontal-related indexes (O'Leary index, plaque index, gingival index, and subgingival plaques) after using the mouthwash, with effects increasing over time. The mouthwash also demonstrated antibacterial effects against both gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria in subgingival plaques.
population_specificity: 64 patients visiting a dental clinic in Busan, Korea, excluding those with insufficient data.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of 1% and 2% pilocarpine mouthwash on salivary flow in participants with xerostomia.
results_summary: Both 1% and 2% pilocarpine mouthwash significantly increased salivary flow compared to placebo, with the 2% formulation showing greater efficacy. No side effects were observed in any participants.
population_specificity: 48 subjects with xerostomia.
effective_dosage: 5 ml of 1% or 2% pilocarpine mouthwash, used three times daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-caries effect of a mouthwash containing Lespedeza cuneata extract by assessing its impact on acid-producing capacity and caries-causing bacteria.
results_summary: The study found that the mouthwash significantly reduced dental caries activity and caries-causing bacteria from treatment to 5 days post-use (p < 0.05), confirming its effectiveness in preventing and inhibiting caries progression.
population_specificity: 82 subjects (42 in the treatment group, 40 in the placebo group) with standardized oral environments.
effective_dosage: Once daily before bedtime for 5 days.

study_goal: To evaluate the effects of chlorhexidine (CHX) mouthwash on gingivitis in patients undergoing orthodontic treatment with fixed appliances.
results_summary: CHX mouthwash reduced plaque accumulation and gingival inflammation during orthodontic treatment, with comparable effectiveness to other mouthwashes containing propolis, probiotics, or herbs. No significant difference was found between CHX and alternative mouthwashes in terms of gingival index at 3-4 weeks.
population_specificity: 602 patients aged 11-35 years undergoing orthodontic treatment with fixed appliances.
effective_dosage: 0.06%, 0.12%, or 0.2% CHX mouthwash (specific frequency not detailed).
study_duration: Varied from 1 day to nearly 5 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chlorhexidine mouthwash improves gingival health around orthodontic miniscrew implants (OMIs) and enhances their survivability.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant differences in gingival health or OMI survivability between the chlorhexidine mouthwash group and the placebo group at any time point. One OMI was lost in the chlorhexidine group, and two were lost in the control group, with no significant difference in survivability.
population_specificity: 32 participants (mean age 22.8 years) undergoing fixed orthodontic treatment after maxillary premolar extraction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of chitosan mouthwash versus chlorhexidine mouthwash in reducing plaque accumulation and gingival inflammation.
results_summary: Both chitosan and chlorhexidine mouthwashes significantly reduced plaque accumulation, gingival inflammation, and colony-forming units, but a combination of both was reported as more effective. The included studies had varying risks of bias, with one showing low risk and two showing high risk.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population with plaque accumulation and gingivitis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of fermented lingonberry juice (FLJ) mouthwash on salivary parameters and subjective dry mouth symptoms over a six-month period.
results_summary: FLJ mouthwash significantly improved salivary flow rates, buffering capacity, and pH, while also reducing symptoms of xerostomia. The effects were statistically significant and beneficial for oral health.
population_specificity: 25 adult participants with normal oral homecare routines.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the antimicrobial and antiplaque properties of a mouthwash containing Chlorhexidine (CHX) 0.2% with ADS, PVP-VA, and Sodium DNA compared to a placebo in subjects with chronic periodontitis.
results_summary: The study found significant reductions in plaque (FMPS), bleeding (FMBS), and gingival inflammation (GI) scores in the test group compared to the placebo group after 1 and 2 weeks of treatment. The results were statistically significant (p < 0.05), demonstrating the mouthwash's efficacy in reducing bacterial plaque and gingival inflammation.
population_specificity: Subjects affected by chronic periodontitis (n = 54).
effective_dosage: 0.2% Chlorhexidine mouthwash with ADS, PVP-VA, and Sodium DNA (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the virucidal activity of cetylpyridinium chloride (CPC) mouthwash in reducing SARS-CoV-2 viral load and nucleocapsid protein levels in saliva.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in SARS-CoV-2 viral RNA load between the CPC and control groups, but CPC mouthwash significantly increased nucleocapsid protein levels in saliva at 1 and 3 hours post-intervention, indicating enhanced disruption of viral particles.
population_specificity: Nonhospitalized patients with asymptomatic or mild symptomatic SARS-CoV-2 infection (mean age 46 years).
effective_dosage: 15 mL of 0.07% CPC mouthwash (Vitis CPC Protect), used once for 1 minute.
study_duration: Single intervention with follow-up at 1 and 3 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize current understandings of quaternary ammonium compounds (QACs) in mouthwash, focusing on their antimicrobial actions, resistance mechanisms, and impacts on microecology.
results_summary: The study found that QACs in mouthwash have broad-spectrum antimicrobial effects but may contribute to environmental contamination, microbial resistance, and disruption of microecology. Resistance mechanisms and long-term ecological impacts remain unclear.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of QAC applications).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of goji berry mouthwash versus chlorhexidine mouthwash as adjuncts to scaling and root planing (SRP) in managing periodontitis.
results_summary: Both goji berry and chlorhexidine mouthwash significantly reduced periodontal parameters (PPD, Pi, BOP, Gi) after one month, with no statistically significant difference between them. Goji berry mouthwash was more effective in increasing antioxidant levels in saliva.
population_specificity: 60 adult participants with periodontitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of chlorine-dioxide-containing mouthwash and chlorhexidine mouthwash on the mechanical properties and surface morphology of stainless steel orthodontic archwires compared to artificial saliva.
results_summary: Both chlorine dioxide and chlorhexidine mouthwashes increased the frictional resistance of archwires compared to the control group, though the differences were not statistically significant. Surface roughness measurements at 10μm showed no significant differences among the groups.
population_specificity: Orthodontic archwires (in vitro study, not human subjects)
effective_dosage: Group A - 0.2% chlorhexidine mouthwash; Group B - chlorine dioxide mouthwash (concentration not specified); Group C - artificial saliva

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of 0.05% CPC mouthwash and 0.01% on-demand aqueous chlorine dioxide mouthwash on reducing SARS-CoV-2 viral titers in saliva compared to placebo.
results_summary: The study found that 0.05% CPC mouthwash significantly reduced SARS-CoV-2 viral titers in saliva 10 minutes post-use, while 0.01% on-demand aqueous chlorine dioxide mouthwash showed no significant difference compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Mildly symptomatic COVID-19 patients.
effective_dosage: 20 mL of 0.05% CPC mouthwash, 10 mL of 0.01% on-demand aqueous chlorine dioxide mouthwash, or 20 mL of purified water (placebo), used in a 1:1:1 ratio.
study_duration: Not specified (single-use measurement at 10 minutes post-use).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the evidence for managing patients on antithrombotic therapy undergoing dental procedures, including the use of tranexamic mouthwash to reduce bleeding.
results_summary: The study found that tranexamic mouthwash can be used as a local hemostatic measure to reduce bleeding following minor dental procedures, with minimal risk when antithrombotic therapy is continued. More invasive procedures may require temporary interruption of antithrombotic therapy, depending on individual risk factors.
population_specificity: Patients receiving antithrombotic therapy (antiplatelet or anticoagulant drugs) undergoing dental procedures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of a fresh-breath mild effervescent tablet against mouthwash in reducing halitosis (bad breath) caused by volatile sulphur compounds (VSCs).
results_summary: The study found that the fresh-breath mild effervescent tablet was statistically as effective as mouthwash in reducing VSCs immediately after use (no significant difference, p = 0.38). Mouthwash showed a significant reduction in VSCs compared to baseline (p < 0.01).
population_specificity: 102 volunteers (18-60 years) with oral complaints, narrowed to 61 with confirmed halitosis.
study_duration: Immediate effect test (single use) and effective duration test (measured at 0h, 1h, 2h post-consumption).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of mouthwashes containing different proteins and peptides in preventing enamel erosion in vivo and assess participant satisfaction with the formulations.
results_summary: Mouthwashes with proteins or peptides were significantly more effective than deionized water in preventing enamel erosion, with no significant differences among active ingredients. Participants reported satisfaction with the taste, and no side effects were observed.
population_specificity: 12 participants in a cross-over study design.
effective_dosage: 0.1 mg/mL CaneCPI-5; 0.5 mg/mL MaquiCPI-3; 0.1 mg/mL CsinCPI-2; 0.037 mg/mL Stn15pSpS; rinsed for 1 min.
study_duration: Short-term (single rinse per phase with 2-hour AEP formation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the association between oral hygiene behaviors, including mouthwash use, and cognitive decline in adults.
results_summary: The study found that mouthwash use was not associated with the risk of dementia or cognitive decline, unlike toothbrushing, which showed significant benefits. Other oral hygiene behaviors, including mouthwash, did not demonstrate a significant impact on cognitive outcomes.
population_specificity: Adults, including older adults with moderate-to-severe dementia.
study_duration: Follow-up periods ranged from 30 days to 48 months for interventions and 9 to 18 years for cohorts.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of a professional chlorhexidine alternative mouthrinse as an adjunct to toothbrushing for plaque removal and gingivitis reduction.
results_summary: The study found that using mouthwash after toothbrushing optimized plaque removal and improved gingival health. The mouthrinse was effective in enhancing oral hygiene when combined with sodium fluoride toothpaste.
population_specificity: Not specified (single-center study, likely general adult population with gingival inflammation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antibacterial activity, cellular toxicity, and clinical effects (plaque accumulation and gingival bleeding) of chlorhexidine wax-coated dental floss compared to a control.
results_summary: Chlorhexidine-coated floss showed dose-dependent antibacterial activity against S. mutans but 2% concentration was highly toxic in vitro. The 0.12% and 1% concentrations significantly reduced gingival bleeding but did not affect plaque accumulation.
population_specificity: 27 participants (specific demographics not provided).
effective_dosage: 0%, 0.12%, and 1% chlorhexidine wax-coated dental floss, used once daily.

study_goal: To investigate the stain-preventing ability and efficacy of a new chlorhexidine mouthwash compared to a commercially available one in reducing plaque, gingivitis, and staining.
results_summary: The new mouthwash reduced staining by 42.6% compared to the commercial mouthwash while showing equivalent efficacy in reducing gingivitis, plaque, and plaque bacteria.
population_specificity: 98 subjects (with a subset of 62 evaluated for plaque bacteria).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the antiplaque and antigingivitis efficacy of 0.12% chlorhexidine (CHX) and 5% Malva sylvestris mouthwashes.
results_summary: Both mouthwashes showed similar antiplaque effects, but CHX demonstrated significantly greater reduction in gingival inflammation compared to Malva sylvestris.
population_specificity: 44 participants in a randomized crossover clinical study.
effective_dosage: 0.12% CHX and 5% Malva sylvestris mouthwash solutions.

study_goal: To evaluate the antibacterial efficacy of Ayurvedic (Hiora) and triclosan-based mouthwashes compared to normal saline in children.
results_summary: The Ayurvedic Hiora mouthwash showed the greatest reduction in salivary bacterial colony counts, followed by the triclosan-based mouthwash, with saline being the least effective.
population_specificity: 45 healthy children aged 10-15 years.
study_duration: Saliva samples were collected pre-rinse and at 2, 30, and 60 minutes post-rinsing.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to address controversies and establish best practices for oral care, including the use of mouthwash, in hemato-oncology patients and hematopoietic cell transplantation recipients.
results_summary: The study found that chlorhexidine (CHX) oral rinse may reduce oral infection risk but not oral mucositis, and lidocaine mouthwash can palliate oral pain when used appropriately.
