Toothbrushing was preferred over cleansing swabs, and daily toothbrush replacement was deemed unnecessary.
population_specificity: Hemato-oncology patients and hematopoietic cell transplantation recipients (HCT).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a dipotassium oxalate-containing mouthwash, diode laser, and their combination on dentinal tubule occlusion for treating dentin hypersensitivity.
results_summary: The study found that all treatment groups achieved dentinal tubule occlusion, with the combined mouthwash and laser treatment showing the most pronounced effects compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Human single-rooted third molars (in vitro dentin samples).
effective_dosage: 1.4% dipotassium oxalate mouthwash applied twice for 60 seconds over a 5-day period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the anti-caries effects of a mouthwash containing Cibotium barometz J. Smith (CB) extract against chlorhexidine and saline solutions.
results_summary: The CB mouthwash group showed significant improvements in plaque index, caries activity, and bacterial tests over one and two weeks compared to saline and chlorhexidine groups, with statistically significant differences in interaction effects.
population_specificity: 76 study participants in a randomized, blinded clinical trial.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether a mouthwash combining hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) and hyaluronic acid (HA) improves socket healing and reduces post-operative complications after third molar surgery.
results_summary: The study found significant reductions in pain and other healing parameters in the H2O2 and HA group compared to placebo, suggesting a positive effect on socket healing. No dropouts or adverse events were reported, indicating good tolerability.
population_specificity: 114 patients who underwent third molar extraction (impacted, partially erupted, or completely erupted) at a dental hospital in Milan, Italy.
effective_dosage: Not specified (only mentions "H2O2 and HA combination").

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an integral therapy combining oral hygiene (using neutral electrolyzed water mouthwash) and systemic treatment could improve eradication rates of gastric H. pylori infection and reduce recurrences.
results_summary: Integral therapy with neutral electrolyzed water mouthwash (NEW) and periodontal treatment (NEW-PT) significantly increased gastric eradication rates (84%-96%) compared to normal saline (20%-56%) and showed protective effects against recurrences (81.2%) and treatment failure (76.6%). NEW was recommended as an effective antiseptic mouthwash.
population_specificity: Double-positive (oral and gastric H. pylori infection) patients.
effective_dosage: Not specified (mouthwash used as part of oral hygiene protocol).
study_duration: Evaluated at one and four months post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the preventive and therapeutic effects of rebamipide gargle versus benzydamine in head and neck cancer patients undergoing radiotherapy with or without chemotherapy.
results_summary: Rebamipide mouthwash was as effective as benzydamine in minimizing severe oral mucositis (WHO grade 3), with no significant differences in incidence, onset, or duration. Rebamipide showed superiority in reducing the severity of radiation-induced oral mucositis, and both prevented WHO grade 4 mucositis.
population_specificity: Head and neck cancer patients receiving high-dose radiotherapy.
study_duration: January 2021 to August 2022 (exact intervention duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of sodium fluoride (NaF) and chlorhexidine (CHX) mouthwashes on the surface roughness of nickel-titanium orthodontic archwires compared to regular oral hygiene.
results_summary: The study found significant differences in surface roughness between the control group (regular oral hygiene) and the NaF and CHX groups, with NaF causing more significant alterations. No significant difference was observed between the NaF and CHX groups.
population_specificity: Patients using nickel-titanium orthodontic archwires.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antibacterial effectiveness of a combination of ε-poly-L-lysine, funme peptide, and domiphen in a mouthwash, and assess its efficacy in reducing halitosis and supragingival plaque in a clinical trial.
results_summary: The mouthwash demonstrated significant antibacterial effects against oral pathogens, reduced volatile sulfur compounds by 50.27% in the test group, and decreased the Plaque Index by 54.55% after 7 days, with no toxicity to human gingival fibroblasts.
population_specificity: Not specified beyond participants in a clinical trial.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of a mixed mouthwash (lidocaine, sodium alginate, sucralfate, pheniramine), hyaluronic acid, and sodium bicarbonate solution in treating oral mucositis in pediatric patients post-hematopoietic stem cell transplantation.
results_summary: Hyaluronic acid (Group 2) showed statistically significant lower mucositis scale scores compared to the mixed mouthwash (Group 1) and sodium bicarbonate (Group 3), particularly on days 5 and 10 post-transplantation, suggesting superior efficacy.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients with hemato-oncological malignancies undergoing allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation.
study_duration: Measurements taken on transplant day and days 5, 10, 15, and 20 post-transplantation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 0.05% CPC or 0.01% on-demand aqueous chlorine dioxide mouthwash reduces SARS-CoV-2 salivary viral load in COVID-19 patients compared to placebo.
results_summary: Neither 0.05% CPC nor 0.01% on-demand aqueous chlorine dioxide mouthwash significantly reduced SARS-CoV-2 viral load at any measured time point (30 min to 24 hours) compared to placebo. The study found no statistically or clinically meaningful differences between the active mouthwashes and placebo.
population_specificity: Asymptomatic to mildly symptomatic adult COVID-19-positive patients.
effective_dosage: 20 mL of 0.05% CPC, 10 mL of 0.01% on-demand aqueous chlorine dioxide, or 20 mL of placebo (purified water), used once.
study_duration: Single administration with follow-up measurements up to 24 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of octenidine hydrochloride and chlorhexidine mouthwashes as adjuncts to instrumentation in reducing periodontal parameters in patients with stage I-II periodontitis.
results_summary: Octenidine and chlorhexidine mouthwashes significantly reduced gingival inflammation compared to placebo, with octenidine causing less staining and being the preferred choice based on patient-reported VAS scores.
population_specificity: 45 patients with mild-to-moderate (stage I-II) periodontitis.
effective_dosage: 0.1% octenidine dihydrochloride and 0.12% chlorhexidine mouthwashes, used twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining mouthwash with Tegaderm (BTMT) improved oral mucosal health and reduced complications in intubated patients compared to brushing alone or brushing with mouthwash (BTM).
results_summary: The BTMT group showed lower oral mucositis scores, shorter intubation duration, and a lower incidence of ventilator-associated pneumonia compared to the other groups, though pneumonia differences were not statistically significant.
population_specificity: Intubated patients (n=70) in a hospital setting.
study_duration: Intervention effects were measured from Day 2 to Day 4 post-baseline.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antibacterial and clinical benefits of a new mouthwash containing an amine + zinc lactate + fluoride system for reducing plaque and gingivitis.
results_summary: The mouthwash demonstrated long-term antibacterial activity in vitro and significantly reduced plaque and gingivitis parameters after 3 and 6 months of use compared to a negative control. Site-level and subject-level analyses showed increased healthy oral sites and improved gum health.
population_specificity: Patients experiencing gum inflammation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-demineralizing effect and irritation potential of a mouthwash containing pomegranate peel extract, sodium trimetaphosphate, and fluoride compared to other formulations.
results_summary: The ETF formulation (PPE + TMP + F) was most effective in preventing enamel demineralization, showed higher calcium and phosphorus retention, and reduced extracellular polysaccharides in biofilms. It also demonstrated lower irritation potential compared to the commercial mouthwash.
population_specificity: Twelve volunteers in a double-blind crossover study.
effective_dosage: Dropped onto enamel twice daily (specific volume not stated).
study_duration: Four phases of 7 days each (total 28 days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of HABITPRO mouthwash as an adjunct to mechanical cleaning in maintaining oral hygiene during maxillomandibular fixation.
results_summary: HABITPRO mouthwash maintained stable plaque control and significantly reduced salivary ammonia levels compared to placebo, suggesting better oral hygiene and reduced bacterial counts. The placebo group showed increased plaque accumulation over the same period.
population_specificity: 55 patients who had undergone maxillomandibular fixation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether mouthwashes containing CPC+Zn or CPC alone could reduce SARS-CoV-2 viral load in the saliva of COVID-19 patients.
results_summary: CPC+Zn mouthwash reduced viral load by 6.34-fold immediately after rinsing (T1), 3.6-fold at T2, and 1.9-fold at T3, while CPC alone reduced it by 2.5-fold at T1, 1.9-fold at T2, and 2.0-fold at T3. The effects lasted up to 60 minutes post-rinsing.
population_specificity: Symptomatic COVID-19 patients with high SARS-CoV-2 viral load in saliva.
effective_dosage: 0.075% cetylpyridinium chloride plus 0.28% zinc lactate (CPC+Zn) and CPC mouthwash (concentration not specified).
study_duration: Immediate effects measured up to 60 minutes post-rinsing.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether early use of saline or chlorhexidine gluconate mouthwash could prevent olfactory and gustatory dysfunctions (OGDs) in COVID-19 patients.
results_summary: Both saline and chlorhexidine gluconate mouthwash significantly reduced the prevalence and severity of OGDs compared to the control group, with the drug group (chlorhexidine gluconate) showing slightly better efficacy (8.3% vs. 11.8% prevalence).
population_specificity: COVID-19 patients admitted to hospitals without OGDs on admission.
study_duration: From admission to discharge (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of propolis mouthwash versus chlorhexidine mouthwash in reducing plaque and gingivitis.
results_summary: Propolis mouthwash showed statistically significant greater reductions in plaque and gingival scores compared to chlorhexidine and placebo mouthwashes after 21 days of use. The study concluded that propolis mouthwash could be an effective herbal alternative to chlorhexidine.
population_specificity: 45 subjects with chronic generalized gingivitis from a dental clinic in Malaysia.
effective_dosage: 0.2% Propolis mouthwash, used twice daily for 1 minute.
study_duration: 21 days per phase, with a 15-day washout period between phases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the salivary drug concentration of CPC buccal tablets and their antiviral effect against SARS-CoV-2 in vitro.
results_summary: The study found that CPC buccal tablets achieved high salivary concentrations, potentially inhibiting SARS-CoV-2 activity for approximately 30 minutes without cytotoxicity. Salivary CPC concentrations were highest at 15 minutes post-administration and declined over 2 hours.
population_specificity: 10 Chinese healthy subjects

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether hyaluronic acid (HyA) application, including as a mouthwash, improves healing or complication management after tooth extraction compared to other treatments or no treatment.
results_summary: HyA mouthwash showed a positive effect on soft tissue healing after non-surgical extraction of normally erupted teeth and significantly reduced pain 7 days postoperatively after surgical removal of lower third molars, though it did not affect early post-operative pain, trismus, or swelling.
population_specificity: Patients with ≥1 tooth extracted, including those undergoing surgical removal of lower third molars and non-surgical extraction of normally erupted teeth.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the impact of commonly used OTC mouthwashes on the oral microbiome, including bacteria, viruses, bacteriophages, and fungi, and assess their potential to cause dysbiosis and antimicrobial resistance.
results_summary: The review found that certain mouthwashes, like chlorhexidine, have proven antimicrobial actions but may disrupt the oral microbiome, leading to dysbiosis. There is limited evidence on their effects on fungi and viruses in vivo, and emerging concerns about antimicrobial resistance due to widespread use.
population_specificity: General oral microbiome (not specific to a human subpopulation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a multicomponent oral care regimen, including a CPC + Zn mouthwash, in reducing gingival bleeding and inflammation in patients with gingivitis.
results_summary: The DZA/CPC + Zn group showed significantly greater reductions in gingival and plaque indices compared to the control group over 6 months, but differences diminished after both groups used similar fluoride toothpaste regimens. The regimen effectively reduced gingival inflammation and supragingival biofilm.
population_specificity: 94 participants with gingivitis.
effective_dosage: Mouthwash containing 0.075% CPC and 0.28% zinc lactate (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of betamethasone mouthwash, both alone and combined with colchicine tablets, for treating Recurrent Aphthous Stomatitis (RAS) and to determine the optimal treatment duration.
results_summary: The study found that betamethasone mouthwash significantly reduced ulcer severity by 30% within 3 months and by 50% after 9 months, with 86% of participants showing clinical improvement. No significant differences were observed between the three treatment regimes.
population_specificity: 106 patients with Recurrent Aphthous Stomatitis (RAS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of chlorhexidine (CHX)-based mouthwashes and gels, with or without anti-discolouration systems (ADS), on the staining of composite restorative materials.
results_summary: CHX-containing products caused staining on composite materials, with flowable composites showing higher discolouration than packable composites. ADS-containing products resulted in fewer pigmentations compared to those without ADS.
population_specificity: In vitro study using composite specimens (packable and flowable).
study_duration: The staining cycle was repeated 6 times.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of chlorhexidine (CHX) mouthwash on periodontal status and extrinsic tooth staining in orthodontic patients.
results_summary: CHX mouthwash significantly improved periodontal health (reduced plaque, gingival, and bleeding indexes) but caused mild brown tooth staining after 30 days and expressive extrinsic staining by 60 days. The control group showed no significant changes in any measured indexes.
population_specificity: Orthodontic patients (11-33 years old) with fixed appliances for <16 months.

study_goal: To evaluate the short-term, in situ anti-plaque effect of a 0.1% cymenol mouthwash compared to a placebo.
results_summary: The 0.1% cymenol mouthwash significantly reduced visible and total plaque area compared to the placebo, with reductions in plaque growth rates ranging from 26% to 53% depending on the group and measurement. The effect was consistent and statistically significant across multiple assessments.
population_specificity: Fifty orally healthy participants.
study_duration: Eight days (four days for placebo in one group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility of conducting a larger RCT to investigate the effect of a carrageenan mouthwash on oral HPV infection.
results_summary: The study is a feasibility trial and does not report efficacy results; it focuses on recruitment, retention, compliance, and safety data collection procedures.
population_specificity: 40 participants in a placebo-controlled triple-blinded feasibility RCT.
effective_dosage: Gargling morning and night, and around sexual activities (specific concentration not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the reduction in SARS-CoV-2 viral load and infectivity induced by phthalocyanine mouthwash and nasal spray in patients with mild COVID-19.
results_summary: The study found that phthalocyanine mouthwash and nasal spray significantly reduced viral load, with Group 3 (both mouthwash and nasal spray) achieving a non-contagious viral load level after 72 hours. The reduction in viral load was significantly higher in Group 3 compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Patients with mild COVID-19.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of separators on bacterial count in gingival crevicular fluid (GCF) and assess the efficacy of chlorhexidine mouth rinse versus saline irrigation in reducing bacterial count.
results_summary: Both saline and chlorhexidine groups showed significant reductions in bacterial count from baseline to the 3rd and 7th days after separator placement. Chlorhexidine was more effective than saline, while the control group (brushing only) saw an increase in bacterial count over time.
population_specificity: Healthy individuals aged 18-25 with good oral hygiene, no previous orthodontic treatment, and low gingival/plaque indices.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of FITOPROT mouthwash combined with photobiomodulation therapy and a preventive oral care program on radiotherapy-induced oral mucositis and quality of life in head and neck cancer patients.
results_summary: The study found no statistical differences between the groups for oral mucositis severity or quality of life outcomes, suggesting FITOPROT did not significantly enhance the effects of photobiomodulation and preventive care. Both groups experienced worsened quality of life during radiotherapy.
population_specificity: Head and neck cancer patients undergoing radiotherapy or chemoradiotherapy.
effective_dosage: FITOPROT was used as a mouthwash twice a day.
study_duration: From the first until the last day of radiotherapy (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of probiotic mouth rinse, kidodent mouth rinse, and placebo in reducing Streptococcus mutans and Lactobacillus acidophilus levels in children.
results_summary: Kidodent and probiotic mouth rinses were significantly more effective than placebo in reducing Streptococcus mutans and Lactobacillus acidophilus, with no statistically significant difference between the two active treatments after immediate and 15-day use.
population_specificity: 90 children aged 6-15 years.
effective_dosage: Not specified (frequency of rinsing not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the relationship between the microbiome and Behçet's disease (BD), including the potential role of antibiotic-supplemented mouthwash in reducing pain and ulcers.
results_summary: The study found that antibiotic-supplemented mouthwash reduced pain and ulcers in BD patients, suggesting a beneficial effect on oral symptoms. However, the primary focus was on broader microbiome changes rather than detailed mouthwash efficacy.
population_specificity: Patients with Behçet's disease (BD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the tooth whitening efficacy and tolerability of a plant-based mouthwash regimen (Lumineux Oral Essentials) against hydrogen peroxide whitening strips (Crest 3DWhitestrips).
results_summary: The Lumineux regimen (including mouthwash) showed no statistically significant tooth color changes, while the Crest strips significantly reduced yellowness and improved lightness. Both regimens were well tolerated, with minor oral irritation and tooth sensitivity reported.
population_specificity: Generally healthy adults (average age 40.8 years, 64% female, age range 18-62).
effective_dosage: Mouthwash used once daily (specific volume not stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether antiseptics (chlorhexidine mouthwash) and high-concentration fluorides affect the biomechanical properties of NiTi archwires during orthodontic treatment.
results_summary: The study found that chlorhexidine mouthwash and high-concentration fluorides did not alter the mechanical properties of NiTi wires more than regular oral hygiene. No significant differences in dental arch shape changes were observed between the experimental groups.
population_specificity: 60 individuals aged 12-22 years (53% female) undergoing orthodontic treatment.
effective_dosage: High-concentration fluorides and chlorhexidine were used for intensive prophylaxis during the first month (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of a biosurfactant lipopeptide mucoadhesive gel against chlorhexidine mouthwash (0.2%) and a base treatment in healing oral ulcers.
results_summary: The study found that chlorhexidine mouthwash showed higher efficacy in reducing wound size compared to the biosurfactant lipopeptide gel and base treatment, with significant differences observed by the second and sixth days of treatment. The biosurfactant treatment reduced pain and wound size but was less effective than the routine mouthwash treatment.
population_specificity: 36 volunteers aged 20-41 years with a history of oral ulcers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the clinical efficacy of probiotics for oral health compared to conventional mouthwash treatments like chlorhexidine and fluoride.
results_summary: The study found that probiotic products led to a significant reduction (65%) in dental plaque compared to conventional treatments, suggesting probiotics are a safe and effective alternative. Co-administration of chlorhexidine, fluoride, and probiotics was highlighted as an optimal approach.
population_specificity: 1,612 participants in randomized controlled trials.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of various dental materials, including a natural enzyme mouthwash (Oral7), in preventing dental caries in patients after chemotherapy and radiotherapy for head and neck cancer.
results_summary: The study found that the mouthwash composed of natural enzymes (Oral7) did not demonstrate effectiveness in preventing dental caries, while other materials like CPP-ACP with fluorine and IFRS showed better results.
population_specificity: Patients after chemotherapy and radiotherapy for head and neck cancer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of mouthwashes on oral microorganisms and gingivitis in orthodontic patients.
results_summary: Short-term fluoride mouthwashes reduced Mutans streptococci counts, while long-term effects were unclear. Chlorhexidine and herbal mouthwashes significantly reduced plaque and gingival inflammation indexes in the short-term, though some herbal results lacked statistical significance.
population_specificity: Orthodontic patients
study_duration: Short-term and long-term (specific durations not detailed)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of curcumin mouthwash (0.1% w/v) and curcumin-nanocapsules in reducing the severity and pain of radiation-induced oral mucositis in head and neck cancer patients undergoing radiotherapy.
results_summary: Both curcumin mouthwash and nanocapsules significantly reduced the severity and burning associated with oral mucositis compared to placebo, with over 33% of mouthwash users remaining ulcer-free by study end. The reduction in pain and severity scores was comparable between curcumin groups, with no significant differences.
population_specificity: 37 head and neck cancer patients (mean age 53.36 years, 37.8% women) undergoing radiotherapy with grades 1-3 radiation-induced oral mucositis.
effective_dosage: Curcumin mouthwash (0.1% w/v) used three times daily for 1 minute; Sinacurcumin soft gel (40 mg curcuminoids as nano-micelles) also administered.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of different concentrations of boric acid combined with chlorhexidine mouthwash on postoperative complications and periodontal healing following impacted third molar surgery.
results_summary: The combination of higher concentrations of boric acid with chlorhexidine was more effective in reducing pain, jaw dysfunction, and swelling than chlorhexidine mouthwash alone, with no significant differences in trismus, analgesic use, or periodontal variables. The 2.5% BA + CHX group showed the lowest pain and swelling, while the 2% BA + CHX group had reduced jaw dysfunction.
population_specificity: 80 patients undergoing impacted third molar surgery.
effective_dosage: BA concentrations ranging from 0.1% to 2.5% combined with CHX or 2% BA alone.
study_duration: Follow-up period included postoperative days 4 and 5 (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether propolis mouthwash could prevent oral mucositis in hematological cancer patients receiving high-dose chemotherapy and/or hematopoietic stem cell transplantation.
results_summary: Propolis mouthwash significantly reduced the incidence and duration of oral mucositis and delayed its onset compared to standard oral care alone. The intervention group also experienced later onset of grade 2-3 oral mucositis.
population_specificity: Adults with hematological cancer receiving high-dose chemotherapy and/or hematopoietic stem cell transplantation.
effective_dosage: Aqueous propolis extract (specific dosage not mentioned).
study_duration: Duration not explicitly stated in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the efficacy of a mouthwash containing CPC and CHX at 0.05% each in reducing SARS-CoV-2 viral load and infectivity compared to a placebo.
results_summary: The study found that the mouthwash containing CPC and CHX reduced viral load and infectivity in SARS-CoV-2-positive patients, as measured by quantitative PCR and cell culture infectivity assays, compared to a placebo.
population_specificity: Sixty-one SARS-CoV-2-positive patients with symptom onset within the last 72 hours.
effective_dosage: 20 mL of mouthwash (0.05% CPC and 0.05% CHX) used once for gargling for 60 seconds.
study_duration: Single administration with follow-up measurements after 30 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the impact of antiseptic mouthwash on nitric oxide metabolism and its potential role in chronic diseases.
results_summary: The study found that antiseptic mouthwash disrupts nitrate metabolism to nitric oxide, leading to clinical symptoms of nitric oxide deficiency, which is linked to chronic diseases. It suggests dietary nitrate as a therapeutic strategy to restore nitric oxide production.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of chronic disease populations).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antiplaque and antibacterial effects of a mouthwash containing Lespedeza cuneata (LC) extract on periodontal disease indicators and PD-causing bacteria.
results_summary: The LC extract mouthwash significantly reduced the O'Leary index, plaque index, and gingival index scores after 5 days, along with reductions in PD-inducing Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria, demonstrating its effectiveness in improving periodontal health and preventing disease.
population_specificity: 63 subjects divided into two groups (32 using LC extract mouthwash, 31 using saline).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether prophylactic dexamethasone mouthwash is superior to therapeutic dexamethasone mouthwash in reducing the incidence or severity of mTOR inhibitor-associated stomatitis (mIAS) in patients taking everolimus.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences between prophylactic and therapeutic dexamethasone mouthwash in reducing mIAS incidence or pain severity. Additionally, no association was found between everolimus trough concentrations and toxicity.
population_specificity: Patients initiating 10 mg daily oral everolimus.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if mouthwashes containing chlorhexidine (CHX) effectively reduce the COVID-19 virus load in saliva.
results_summary: The review found mixed but generally positive evidence, with most clinical and in vitro studies showing CHX mouthwash reduces SARS-CoV-2 viral load, though some studies reported no effect. One study noted a 99.9% reduction in viral load with a 30-second contact time.
population_specificity: Not restricted by gender, age, or ethnicity; included both clinical and in vitro studies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-inflammatory and anti-bacterial effects of mouthwashes in critical care patients.
results_summary: The study found a significant reduction in ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) incidence with mouthwash use but no significant differences in mortality, duration of mechanical ventilation, or colonization rates.
population_specificity: Intensive care unit (ICU) patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether home-use mouthwashes containing potassium salts effectively reduce and control dentin hypersensitivity (DH).
results_summary: The study found that potassium salt mouthwashes significantly reduced DH after two, four, and eight weeks of use, with no differences in side effects compared to the control group. The results were consistent across tactile and evaporative stimulus tests.
population_specificity: Individuals with dentin hypersensitivity.
effective_dosage: Daily household mouthwash use (specific concentration not detailed).
study_duration: At least four weeks, with follow-up at two, four, and eight weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of nanomicelle curcumin-based photodynamic therapy (NMCur-aPDT) and VITIS® anti-caries mouthwash on microbial count, virulence of Streptococcus mutans, and the development of white spot lesions (WSLs) in orthodontic patients.
results_summary: NMCur-aPDT and VITIS® mouthwash significantly reduced S. mutans population and gtfB gene expression, with NMCur-aPDT showing the highest reduction (99.98%). Both treatments also reduced the mean number and laser fluorescence values of WSLs, unlike LED treatment, which increased WSLs.
population_specificity: 48 patients with fixed orthodontic appliances.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether mouthwash and dentifrice containing an antimicrobial phthalocyanine derivative (APD) could reduce clinical symptoms in COVID-19 patients.
results_summary: The study found a statistically significant reduction in multiple COVID-19 symptoms in the APD group compared to the control group, with fewer symptoms reported at follow-up intervals. The control group showed higher prevalence of symptoms at later time points.
population_specificity: 134 patients aged 18+ with confirmed COVID-19 via RT-qPCR, no contraindications to mouthwash/gargle, and access to communication apps.
effective_dosage: 5 mL mouthwash gargled/rinse for 1 minute, 3 times daily; brushing teeth for 2 minutes, 3 times daily; flossing twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the antimicrobial activity of chlorhexidine mouthwash with another mouthwash (group II) and a control group in fixed orthodontic patients.
results_summary: The study found that chlorhexidine mouthwash (group I) showed a moderate reduction in plaque index (PI) and gingival index (GI) scores compared to the control group, but group II (unspecified mouthwash) had minimal PI reduction. Chlorhexidine was associated with side effects like tooth discoloration and dry mouth.
population_specificity: 90 fixed orthodontic patients.
effective_dosage: Not specified (patients rinsed with respective mouthwashes twice daily).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of three commercially available mouthwashes in suppressing morning bad breath after a single evening rinse.
results_summary: The study found that ChxC mouthwash resulted in the highest number of patients being free from bad breath after 12 hours, while the other tested mouthwashes did not perform better than placebo. Instrumental examination confirmed low volatile sulfur compound (VSC) levels after 12 hours for all tested mouthwashes.
population_specificity: 32 subjects refraining from oral hygiene for 12 hours before evaluation.
effective_dosage: 15 ml for a 30-second rinse followed by a 5-second gargle.
study_duration: Single administration with a 1-week washout period between different mouthwashes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of chlorhexidine (CHG) and ozonated water (OZW) mouthwash in reducing the risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) in ICU patients on mechanical ventilation.
results_summary: Both CHG and OZW mouthwash reduced VAP risk, but OZW was more effective (25% incidence vs. 45.9% with CHG). The most common pathogens in CHG were Acinetobacter baumannii, while OZW had A. baumannii and Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
population_specificity: ICU patients on mechanical ventilation (n=73).
study_duration: Assessed on the first, third, and fifth days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether a mouthwash containing 0.07% cetylpyridinium chloride (CPC) could reduce SARS-CoV-2 viral load in saliva of COVID-19 patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in viral load reduction via RT-qPCR between the CPC and placebo groups. However, the CPC group showed a significant increase in SARS-CoV-2 nucleocapsid protein concentration, suggesting virus lysis.
population_specificity: 80 COVID-19 patients (40 test, 40 placebo).
study_duration: Single rinse with follow-up at 2 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of myrrh and chlorhexidine gluconate mouthwashes on postoperative pain and tissue healing after dental implant placement.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant differences in postoperative swelling, pain, bleeding, or redness between the two mouthwash groups, but myrrh mouthwash showed a positive impact on wound healing in the acute phase.
population_specificity: 35 patients (18 in the myrrh group, 17 in the chlorhexidine gluconate group) who underwent dental implant placement without preoperative infection symptoms and committed to better oral hygiene.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical effects of Salvadora persica-extract mouthwash and chlorhexidine gluconate mouthwash for anti-plaque and anti-gingivitis functions.
results_summary: Salvadora persica-extract mouthwash significantly reduced plaque and gingival inflammation, though it was inferior to chlorhexidine gluconate mouthwash. The meta-analysis included 16 studies, showing a standardized mean difference of 0.89 [95% CI 0.09 to 1.69].
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the prevalence and proportions of bacteria resistant to antiseptics commonly used in dentistry, including mouthwash ingredients like chlorhexidine, triclosan, and cetylpyridinium chloride.
results_summary: The study found bacterial resistance to chlorhexidine (in Streptococcus mutans and Lactobacillus acidophilus) and triclosan (in Veillonella spp.), but no resistance to cetylpyridinium chloride or medicinal herbal formulations. Resistance increased over time for some species.
population_specificity: 442 patients across five randomized clinical trials.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of various oral care interventions, including mouthwash, for palliative patients with oral cavity conditions.
results_summary: Six out of seven studies showed positive results for interventions, including mouthwash, with effect magnitudes ranging from 13.2-10,110.0%. Four studies reported statistically significant improvements, while one trial did not show improvement.
population_specificity: Palliative patients with head-and-neck cancer, oral cancer, oral mucositis, xerostomia, and malignant disease.

study_goal: To assess the clinical effectiveness of herbal dental products (including mouthwash) compared to conventional products or placebo in periodontitis patients.
results_summary: Herbal mouthwash used as an adjunct to scaling and root planing (SRP) or supragingival debridement (SPD) showed superior clinical outcomes compared to placebo or no adjuncts, and comparable or better outcomes than chlorhexidine in some cases.
population_specificity: Periodontitis patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of chlorhexidine mouthwash and gel in preventing and treating alveolar osteitis (dry socket) following tooth extraction.
results_summary: Chlorhexidine mouthwash (0.12% and 0.2%) and gel (0.2%) significantly reduced the risk of dry socket compared to placebo, with moderate-certainty evidence. Minor adverse reactions (e.g., taste alteration, tooth staining) were noted for mouthwash, but no adverse events were reported for the gel.
population_specificity: Adults over 18 years undergoing permanent tooth extraction, primarily third molars extracted by oral surgeons.
effective_dosage: 0.12% and 0.2% chlorhexidine mouthwash (rinsed before and 24 hours post-extraction); 0.2% chlorhexidine gel (placed intrasocket post-extraction).
study_duration: Rinsing before and 24 hours after extraction; gel application post-extraction (duration not specified beyond immediate placement).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the current practices and training needs of ICU nurses regarding oral care, including mouthwash use, for postoperative oral cancer patients.
results_summary: The study found that physiological saline solution was the most commonly used mouthwash (82.7%), but there was significant variability in oral care practices. Nearly all nurses expressed a need for standardized training, particularly on mouthwash selection and usage.
population_specificity: ICU nurses and head nurses from 19 ICUs in 11 tertiary hospitals in Henan province, China, caring for postoperative oral cancer patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the efficacy of mouthwash products containing chlorine dioxide in treating halitosis through a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in organoleptic test scores and volatile sulfur compound levels in the chlorine dioxide group compared to placebo, with no reported side effects. The results were consistent across one-day and one-week follow-ups.
population_specificity: Adults with halitosis

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of chlorhexidine (CHX)-containing mouthwash in maintaining gingival health among orthodontic patients with fixed appliances.
results_summary: CHX-containing mouthwash was associated with significant improvements in Gingival Index, Plaque Index, Bleeding Index, and Pocket Probing Depth in the short-term, but no considerable benefits were found for CHX-gel or CHX-varnish.
population_specificity: Orthodontic patients with fixed appliances (1001 patients across 20 RCTs).
study_duration: Short-term (specific duration not mentioned in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the influence of a red wine mouthwash and diet on tooth bleaching treatment velocity, clinical results, postoperative tooth sensitivity, and patient satisfaction.
results_summary: No significant differences in tooth shade changes were found between groups using red wine mouthwash and those without. However, the group restricted from colored foods without red wine mouthwash showed meaningful variations in tooth shade at T7. Patients in this group reported higher satisfaction post-treatment.
population_specificity: 45 subjects undergoing home tooth bleaching with 16% carbamide peroxide.
effective_dosage: Not specified for mouthwash (only 16% carbamide peroxide for bleaching).
study_duration: 30 days (assessed at T0, T7, T15, T30).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of antimicrobial mouthwashes on the composition of the human oral microbiome.
results_summary: Daily use of mouthwashes, particularly chlorhexidine (CHX) and cetylpyridinium chloride (CPC), was associated with changes in the oral microbiome, including reduced microbial diversity and shifts in specific bacterial abundances. N-acetyl cysteine-based mouthwashes showed no significant changes.
population_specificity: Adult individuals who rinse with antimicrobial mouthwashes.
study_duration: Varied (e.g., 7-day use for CHX, prolonged use for other effects)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and side effects of alcohol-free 0.05% CPC mouthwash, 0.12% CHX mouthwash, and a placebo in reducing plaque accumulation and gingival inflammation when used as an adjunct to toothbrushing.
results_summary: After 6 weeks, both CPC and CHX mouthwashes significantly reduced plaque and gingivitis compared to placebo, with no significant difference between them. CPC caused fewer side effects (taste alteration, numbness) than CHX, and staining scores were lower but not significantly different.
population_specificity: 219 university students
effective_dosage: 0.05% CPC mouthwash and 0.12% CHX mouthwash (frequency not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effects of fluoride agents, particularly fluoride mouthwash, on the corrosion of metallic orthodontic materials.
results_summary: The study found that fluoride agents, especially acidulated fluoride, influence the corrosion of orthodontic metallic appliances, with Co-Cr brackets being resistant while stainless steel and Ti brackets are susceptible. The degree of corrosion correlates with fluoride concentration and medium acidity.
population_specificity: Orthodontic patients with metallic appliances.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether fermented lingonberry juice (FLJ) as a mouthwash could reduce inflammation (aMMP-8 and BOP) and microbial load (VPI) around dental implants.
results_summary: FLJ mouthwash reduced aMMP-8, VPI, and BOP levels, but the difference compared to the control group was not significant. The reduction in aMMP-8 appeared to continue even after discontinuing the mouthwash.
population_specificity: Individuals with at least one dental implant in the anterior or posterior areas with a screw-retained crown.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of four different antiseptic mouthwashes in reducing SARS-CoV-2 salivary viral load and infectious capacity in COVID-19 patients.
results_summary: The study found that some mouthwashes currently used to reduce viral infectivity were not efficient, as they did not significantly lower SARS-CoV-2 viral load or infectious capacity in saliva.
population_specificity: 54 COVID-19 patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of phytochemicals, including aloe vera mouthwash, to corticosteroids in treating oral lichen planus (OLP).
results_summary: The study suggests that phytochemicals, including aloe vera mouthwash, may be an effective alternative to current OLP therapies due to reduced side effects and potential long-term benefits, though specific efficacy data for mouthwash alone is not detailed.
population_specificity: Patients with oral lichen planus (OLP).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of magnetized water and 0.2% chlorhexidine mouthwash on gingivitis and plaque prevention in children over 21 days.
results_summary: Both magnetized water and chlorhexidine were similarly effective in managing periodontal and gingival infections, but magnetized water had fewer side effects like bitter taste and brown stains. Magnetized water was deemed a safer and more acceptable alternative due to its better flavor and lower incidence of adverse effects.
population_specificity: Children aged 12-15 years.
effective_dosage: 140 mL of mouthrinse (magnetized water or 0.2% chlorhexidine) for home use.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of topical Cyclosporine-A (Cyc-A) in treating various mucocutaneous disorders, including its use as a mouthwash.
results_summary: Topical Cyc-A was effective in treating oral lichen planus and other conditions, but adverse effects like dysphagia, burning sensation, and lip swelling were reported with mouthwash use. It was deemed a safe and efficient alternative to long-term steroid treatments.
population_specificity: Patients with immune-mediated mucocutaneous conditions such as oral lichen planus, psoriasis, and burning mouth syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of probiotic tablets on peri-implant mucositis after scaling compared to a placebo.
results_summary: The study found a statistically significant improvement in the bleeding on probing (BOP) index in the probiotic group compared to the placebo group after 28 days, but no difference in probing depth (PD) index values.
population_specificity: 25 volunteer patients with peri-implant mucositis from a private clinic in Mashhad.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the effects of chlorhexidine mouthwash on osteoblasts and the surface topography of dental implants, particularly in the context of peri-implantitis.
results_summary: Chlorhexidine mouthwash alters dental implant surface topography and causes cytotoxicity in osteoblasts, potentially hindering re-osseointegration and leading to implant failure. The study recommends against its use as a surface decontaminant for peri-implantitis.
population_specificity: Human studies, randomized control trials, in vitro studies, and review articles focused on dental implants and peri-implantitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of mouthwash in addition to scaling and root planning (SRPM) on perinatal outcomes, including preterm birth and low birth weight, during pregnancy.
results_summary: The study found that SRPM significantly reduced the risk of preterm birth (RR = 0.37; 95% CI = 0.16-0.84; P = .017) and improved perinatal outcomes compared to control groups.
population_specificity: Pregnant individuals with periodontal disease.
